ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Researching and writing skills. How to be a historian
This course was awesome. Great review of piracy, but most importantly a walkthrough of what historiography is and how different historians operate.

Is the pirates life really for you? How to get the pirate booty? How to walk the plank with grace. 

Seriously: How to analyze primary sources and historiographical skills
I learned a lot about the age of piracy and that era of history in general. I loved the class and also was learned how to approach righting a historiography essay and a long research paper.
Evaluating the historiographical environment of sources in order to investigate the validity of sources

This is an excellent class in which to learn the process of writing history. As Yale does not have a methods course for history, this class is most clear and concise insight I've received in 4 years on how a historian should work. You learn how to move from a general interest in a topic, to exploring the secondary literature, to diving into a historiography, to exploring primary sources and writing a full paper. 

I also learned a ton about the historiography of piracy and piracy suppression, which was fascinating.
I gained a better understanding firstly of pirates and piracy throughout history. I also learned about concepts like empire, jurisdiction, and maritime law.
so much about maritime history, slavery, sea shanties, social history and much more!
I learned a decent amount about maritime law and piracy!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths  Professor Bentons attentiveness and knowledge on the tooic

Strengths: you will never see the inside of Davy Jones' locker
Weaknesses: arghhhhh

Actual strengths: great professor who really cares, course well-facilitated for learning, and engaging discussion
actual weaknesses: some of the readings were a bit boring, legal history can be intimidating
The course itself was great but student engagement varied week by week in reading discussion so perhaps the Professor should call on people randomly

Strengths: Prof. Benton is an excellent teacher, who not only leads discussion well but also does a great job explaining how to write history in class and in office hours. The material is also fascinating. Additionally, the students who want to take a pirates class are more fun than your average history seminar! 

Weaknesses: None! Personal preference on my part is that I don't always love historiography work, and this is a lot of that, but the course did teach me to appreciate it more.
It was a great course, couldnt really suggest anything. I loved the essays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Phenomenal class
Yes - one of my favoirite classes at Yale
I would absolutely recommend this course. The conversations and readings were fascinating and it was definitely my favorite class this semester.

Yes, but please come prepared with a parrot or first mate of equal IQ

Actual answer: Yes, as long as they're prepared to read quite a bit
I would recommend it only to someone with a pre-developed interested in the subject matter

Ahoy, matey! So you've come here looking for treasure. Well, me hearty, look no further than this here seminar. 

Genuinely, you absolutely should take this class. If you like pirates, well then let me say no more. Even if you haven't walked further down the plank of fascination with piracy than Pirates of the Caribbean, this class is still amazing. The class teaches you so much about maritime history, legal history, and imperial history. 

Beyond that, this class is the best way to learn how to do the hard work of studying and writing history, particularly since Yale does not have a history methods class. Prof. Benton is a great teacher, and you could not do better than taking her class.
I would recommend it to any students interested in the subject matter. It gives you right what it says on the tin and a lot more.
absolutely! great course on an interesting topic.

Do not take this class if you are not interested in maritime law. That should seem obvious, but the disclaimer is nice. I loved the class, the professor was passionate and excited to teach, the piracy content was fascinating, but there required context that I was not particularly excited about. I think this was the root of my downfall in this class. Because of my disinterest in the context, I am literally dreading checking my grade.
